How to roll dice: "dice+2d6" without the quotes in the email field rolls 2d6. "dice+5d42+23" rolls 5d42+23. "noko+dice+2d6" rolls 2d6 without showing the roll in the email field.

In the rules department, you can look at http://www.4chan.org/rules - all global and board specific rules are in full effect. Apart from that, only two rules are important.

1. BE EXCELLENT TO EACH OTHER.
2. PARTY ON, DUDES. (AND DUDETTES)

>What is Kingdom Death: Monster?
Monster is a Survival Horror Co-Op board game for 1-4 players about hope in a truly dark place. You awaken in a plane of stone faces bathed in eternal darkness known as the Kingdom Death, a place full of freaky (and sometimes psycho-sexual) monstrosities.

Prologue Narration: [YouTube] Kingdom Death: Monster - Prologue (embed)

The Game is broken up into 3 phases:
1. During your Hunt Phase your band of survivors traverse the world of KD in pursuit of their quarry.
2. After successfully tracking your quarry you will begin the Showdown Phase, where you must fell these horrific creatures in order to acquire precious resources.
3. After the battle, your survivors wander home with loot in hand to begin the Settlement Phase. Arm yourself by developing new weapons and bizarre structures to prepare for next year's hunt.

A successful game campaign takes place over the course of 25 to 30 'lantern years' maximum, marked by completing one full phase cycle. Watch as your settlement grows and witness the survivors write their own narrative as they age. Hone your strategy and learn from your mistakes to overcome the immense odds in this cruel and twisted nightmare scape.

>tl;dr
It's basically Darkest Dungeon meets Monster Hunter meets Berserk.

threads.sub: What RPGs will give a varied look into unique systems?
threads.com: Looking into recommendations of which TTRPGs would give my friends and I a good variety of mechanics to choose from. We've already played 3, 3.5, 5th, and OSR, but we want to get away from DND and experience other influences. There's a ton of options, and I'm not sure what would be the best, in terms of experiencing how they handle things differently. We have GURPS currently on the list, but what other system stands out that's rather unique, compared to DND? Genre doesn't matter, as we want to experience different crunch regardless.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86735181
Savage Worlds, lighter than 3.5, still tactical combat base.
Dogs in the Vineyard, prototypical narrative story game that still has depthful dice mechanics.
1st edition Apocalypse World. The begining of pbta and the indi rpg explosion. Intersting in its own rightbut a good base to expand from if you like it.
Kingdom or Microscope. Full story game, diceless, abstract time frame.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86735491
>Is that still good, or has it been outclassed by 2e?
Masquerade and Requiem are very different things. Different settings, different rules, aiming for different goals. From a purely mechanical perspective even a lot of people that prefer VtM will tell you VtR 2e beats it for mechanics. V20 is really a pretty clunky game with some strange choices, and ability design that's never been particularly exciting. VtR 2e is head and shoulders above it in that regard.

It's really the setting and fluff that most of the love for VtM stems from. It's a big setting with a lot of detail that's been around for a long time. VtR handles its setting very differently, deliberately not doing a lot of what VtM did, and so that's mostly what it comes down to there. VtR doesn't give a lot of hard answers for things that happened in ancient history, it leaves gaps in places for GMs to fill in, and generally just handles its setting differently. For my money I prefer both the fluff and the style of the fluff in VtR but YMMV. However fluff doesn't really seem to be what you're after so if you can only read one, I'd read VtR. However you probably can and probably should read both.

>I'm assuming there's not too much difference in the base game between these choices
Very much depends on what you're talking about here. CofD games all have a unified core system they all share. So stats, skills, combat, social stuff, etc, all work the same. There will be additional mechanics in each, and what PCs can do in each is very different. So everything is different except how you'll do mundane stuff and roll dice. oWoD (VtM, etc.) is the same for that last bit but only has fairly similar core systems. Which means you can't really just learn a core ruleset because that might change between games.

Any two games in CofD or oWoD will be very different. Vampire the X and Werewolf the X really are two different games. And as with VtM and VtR the two versions of them are very different too.

Dogs in the Vineyard is definitely on the most unique systems out there. It's not really meant for the long campaigns you have with d&d, though.
Genesys uses funky dice that gives much deeper results than pass/fail, though if your group is on the wrong side of average intelligence, parsing the results may take a long time.
There's a few nip games that are similar in tone to d&d, but have some difference in rules. Sword World is straight fantasy. There's also Kamigakari, a personal (but flawed) favourite of mine, or Double Cross for urban fantasy stuff.
There's also Trail of Cthulu, for a completely different roleplaying experience than d&d. With what it being a horror game and such.

threads.name: /gurpsgen/ - GURPS General
threads.com:
previous thread >>86497735

<<<<<<<< READ THE PDF BEFORE ASKING WHERE TO START

GURPS is a modular, adaptable system, capable of running a wide range of characters, settings, and play styles with level of detail varying from lightweight to completely autistic.
Optional rules allow you to emulate different genres with a single system, even switching genres within a single game.

A nearly complete archive of GURPS books can be found by those who pay attention to file extensions.
Never post direct links to the archive anywhere.

If you're wondering where to start:
The Basic Set covers everything, including a lot of optional rules you probably won't use.
A genre guide can be found in the archive, under Unofficial > GURPSgen. It tells you what extra books and articles you may find useful for many common genres.
How To be a GURPS GM is a good read even for players.
GCS (gurpscharactersheet.com) is an excellent character builder software with page references to all the books and the option to export to both Foundry and Fantasy Grounds.

TQ: Do you spoonfeed or gatekeep?

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Information that makes someone go insane (or become sick, or mutate, or turn evil, or explode)
threads.com:
What are some interesting ways to implement the concept of "supernaturally dangerous knowledge" into a tabletop adventure? When someone hears or reads the knowledge and attempts to comprehend it, they go insane, become sick, mutate, turn evil, explode, or otherwise suffer some horrific fate. Heroic individuals have a chance to resist, but regular people are simply screwed.

As a one-off threat, it could be some shiny book that the PCs might come across. As the centerpiece of an adventure, the party might be trying to stop the dissemination of supernaturally dangerous knowledge, whether due to some nefarious villain's plot, or due to the ignorance of whoever is distributing the tainted media.

In some cases, such knowledge could be likened to a corrupted file on a computer. When the mind opens up the information and attempts to process it, calamity strikes.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86613322
Escalate the situation with quantum physics. The theory fundamentally does not make logical sense (one major problem is that quantum phenomena cannot be described without an observer, unlike everything else in the universe). Yet the math checks out and much of our technology depends on that understanding. Maybe our brains just are not built to comprehend this sort of thing. So again, play it up. Trying to wrap a person's mind around supposedly impossible stuff, like weapons or other technologies that to us only exist on a conceptual or metaphysical level yet have real world effects. You might as well be a child playing with a loaded gun.

It's a thought experiment that carries a miniscule risk of bad but with absolutely zero possibility of good, and that's what upset him.

>>86733872
I've always referred to "quality build" as high dex/middling str so that you qualify for Power Attack and get a dmg bonus for two-handing the weapon. Which in most cases means starting with 14 Str and 18 Dex (after racials). But the Sword Cane is especially poor for quality builds since it can't be two-handed. If you simply want to qualify for TWF then you can take Artful Dodge and use your intelligence for Dex prerequisites.
>https://aonprd.com/FeatDisplay.aspx?ItemName=Artful%20Dodge

And if you're after the "theme" rather than specifically the Sword Cane weapon, then you could use Power of Suggestion to bullshit your way to it. It would be a DC 20 Bluff check to make everyone believe that your Rapier (or another thin, straight blade) is a cane rather than a weapon.
>https://aonprd.com/TraitDisplay.aspx?ItemName=Power%20of%20Suggestion
It should work with Student of Philosophy which is a common Investigator trait. Do note that Power of Suggestion isn't opposed by sense motive. Being a straight DC means nobody gets a chance to resist.

Got a cool DM screen for my birthday recently and I plan to use it in an upcoming campaign. Quick internet searches result in barebones excel sheets so I plan to design a reference sheet that is easier on the eyes.

Besides the obvious like a world map and a quick reference sheet, how do you accessorize?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
My DM's screen used to have all sorts of stuff on it, but over time it dropped to just two things: A post-it with a list of skills, and a post-it (or several) with a list of random names (which I replace after a few games).

I reference the skills often because it's a good way to come up with challenges that test different abilities, while the random names are vital to me because without it I end up coming up with names like "Schmee-salami" if I'm forced to come up with them on the spot.

I had things like NPC trait lists and random encounter tables and initiative trackers (a long time ago I used colored paper clips I rearranged at the top of my screen), but ultimately, it's those two things that I keep on my screen as opposed to in my notes or in my mind.

How many of those there are in a set and how valuable they are will impact how many boxes the game stores and secondary resellers are going to order. last_replies.com:
There is a TCG engine called Dvorak, that I really enjoyed as template for making my own card game. It's meant to be as simple and condensed as possible, and I managed to make a decent starter set/dueling kit with it.

Basically, there's Threats (cards that stay on table and have passive effect, when played) and Attacks (cards that resolve once when played). That's it, two types of cards, and a player can play up to one Threat and one Attack during his turn, encouraging putting both in more or less equal number in your deck.

The third type of card is Goal - while deckbuilding, player picks 3 Goals, which outline specific conditions for completion. The player who completes all 3 of their Goals first, wins. Unfortunately, I lost my PnP file, so the dueling set will remain only as single physical copy (which is good, because it was unbalanced as fuck), but I'll definitely make a second one.

Art on cards is AI-generated (via pixray), picrelated is the only card that survived digitally.

>>86735195
Why ideas for worldbuilding are relevant to tabletop gaming really shouldn't require explanation. But I'll do you a solid, also-offtopic sitposter-kun.
>grating doors & grooved pillars
These provide ways to make maps only partially-accessible to players without it being forced, allowing you to draw out party members or introduce NPCs/mobs from strategic directions.
>Straws
Just adds verisimilitude, I'll grant. Useful for helping to set an atmosphere but not strictly necessary.
>Special door
It's literally an expansion on the classic key-in-statue puzzle. You DO have puzzles in your campaign, right?
>Earrings
Wayfinding is important in a world without GPS. This is another tool in the toolbox for players or NPCs, especially if they're used to stealthily track individuals.
>potato bread
It is a pet peeve of mine how little attention is generally paid to economics/ecology of a setting. Food does not generally appear from nothing. With fleshed out economies, players can take advantage of lateral thinking to solve problems.
>grasping
It is very fun to create situations where confusion can lead to conflict.
>aquatic building
More fleshing out. Strong currents causing trouble is also a trope.
>air curtains
Fluff, I'll admit.
>lenticular clouds
Tend to form by peaks, justifies cloudwalkers building on mountains, defining likely borders. Unusual borders, to boot.
>HnK
I am fond of the idea of the party passing through towns where they cannot actually rest because there is no food or useful shelter. It allows you to dispense campaign events while still putting the pressure.
>fording
Mostly fluff unless you're running a solo RPG, I'll admit.
>floodplains
Turning something as innocuous as a floodplain into a ticking time bomb for any smallfolk party reinforces the scale and provides another natural challenge.
>frequencies
Mobs that don't operate on vision.
>international waters
More border drama. Think bronze age collapse as a campaign.

>What is Genesys?
Released in November 2017, Genesys is a pen-and-paper generic/universal RPG system and toolkit by Fantasy Flight Games and EDGE Studio, using a refined version of the system presented by their Star Wars RPGs (Edge of the Empire, Age of Rebellion, Force and Destiny). Its central mechanic is the Narrative Dice System, using pools made of specialized dice to create narrative results. The intention is for the system to be a highly flexible narrative system, adaptable to most any conceivable setting and premise.

>>>DRAWTHREAD RULES<<<

>Requesters:
• Provide good, detailed references (pictures are better than verbal descriptions), so the artists know what you're looking for.
• Only bump your request once every 24 hours. Don't bump WIPs.
• If you have a WIP quote the Anchor Post, and attach the WIP so your drawfag can find you.
• Do not reply to other deliveries with a request that the artist fill your request next, this is called 'piggybacking'.
• Do not make multiple requests in the same thread and do not serially request multiple characters after a delivery. Suggesting several concepts for artists to choose from counts as making multiple requests.
• If you're unsatisfied with your completed request, please wait at least one week before you re-request. If someone follows this rule, don't waste posts by complaining about it.
• Reminder that nobody is entitled to a delivery under any circumstances within these threads. Don't critique others' requests. If you don't like it, don't draw it.
• Stay on topic

>>86733916
So my problem with your argument should be fairly clear.
>I want to do something good
>But the act of wanting something is inherently selfish
>But if I don't want something, the act isn't of my will
It's an approach that seems to fundamentally exclude the possibility of a good period.
I can understand the approach of discounting someone's efforts to do good because they do good for the sake of the feeling they get for doing it, but the immediate response to that is that the people who object to feeling pleasure from doing good are simply engaging in self-righteousness for their own satisfaction.
You might rightfully object in turn that I'm not fairly representing your position on positive/negative or good and evil. My response to that is if you're going to claim that something isn't present because the situation doesn't allow for it, I would point to the situation itself as proof of the thing's existence.
Claiming that good doesn't exist because nobody can be purely altruistic is kind of like claiming that suffering doesn't exist because the self doesn't exist, and the self is required to exist for suffering to exist. But clearly a situation that's described as suffering does exist, or the solution to the problem wouldn't be necessary.
Maybe my mouth is writing checks my intellect can't cash here, but my point is that saying that you can't seek your own good in the process of being good seems like semantics instead of a meaningful issue. An example I use for this is circles. Any circle you draw in reality certainly isn't a platonic circle, but it's an object that falls into the category of circle functionally.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Hey guys,

I'm making a custom dungeon for my party and I'd love your critique of it.

Here is the background/history description:

I'm making a dungeon, a dragon lair near a top of a mountain with a kobold residence. Since the history of its inhabitants is important, I'll also lay this out here. Setting is Feywild.

The Dragon:

Time dragon was hatched to a half crazed mother and was soon stolen by an evil mummers troupe. Was tortured dancing bear style to be obedient, also his wings were amputated. During this time, a small slave girl and a slave boy were only ones kind to him. Eventually, he was sold to a mercenary group to be used as a shock troop. After this dragon managed to flee into the Mountain range.

Kobold tribe: Hunted by predators of all kinds, kobolds stumbled upon the dragon. They got a protector and he got a tribe of creatures who cared about him.

They picked as their home a large cave near the mountain top of one of the mountains in a Mountain range. Immensely industrious kobolds expanded the dragon cave, made space for their living quarters. For decades, they planned and got magical powers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
During this period, kobold leaders figured, dragon only cared for the company of pretty, kindhearted children. He did not harm them, but this way their "Kobold God" became happy. So, strengthened kobolds(casters and warriors) started raiding Feywild and Material plane for such children.

In order for children not to "degenerate", kobolds came up with organized petrification - a child would be caught, dominated (Dominate person), child would be for a time in company of a dragon, then would be exposed to gaze of a group of 3 Medusas, eho also reside in a dragon lair. When needed, child would be brought back via Greater Restoration. Children were stored in dozens of niches in dragons' lair for him to gaze upon.

Kobolds got pretty darn strong, even got a spell of Regeneration for their "dragon-god" to grow back its wings. With a number of low- to mid- level casters in their ranks as well as a lot of competent fighters, they abandoned their "hunted all the time" fate.

So I guess their lair should be pretty fortified and attack-proof. This is what I was going for.


I know its kind of crude and I think certain conceptual gaps will need to be filled, but I like the fact I gathered the effort to make this, since encounters and roleplay are easy for me, but dungeonbuilding is quite an effort

Thanks

when you buy nuln oil or agarax earthshade, buy a pot of lhamian medium as well. then, using a 3rd empty pot, pour half of each in, so that you get a bottle thats 50% shade, 50% medium, and pour the remainder of the shade into the medium pot or vice versea so you get a second pot thats 50% shade and 50% medium

its still just as strong in the recesses but much much less staining on the surfaces. you do need to make sure to shake your pots before using them when you do this, but you should generally do that with shades anyways

>>86732142
I have two games for ya anon. Onitama and Santorini.
>Onitama
It's conceptually similar to chess, but with less pieces and with cards that dictate your moves. The goal is to either capture your opponents king or have your king move to your opponents temple. To do this you use cards that tell you how to move. Each player has two cards, plus a card held in reserve which is swapped with the played card. You can see your opponents cards, so the strategy comes from predicting your opponents moves and making them make moves that get you the card you want.
>Santorini
Fun little building game. Each player has two builders. Goal is to build a building three blocks high and put a builder on top. However you can block off a tower with a dome. Very simple, very quick, very fun. You can easily run 2 or 3 games in an hour. More if you're good.

>>>Finally, does the setting have any noteworthy texts, especially ones full of arcane and/or forbidden knowledge?

Tons, and it's a point of conflict in the setting. The 'true history' of humanity's past has been altered and changed by three competing authorities to best serve their respective agendas. Nobility and large guilds in all three of these authorities hoard knowledge and and enslave magi who are used as conduits to transform the arcane into useful devices which have fueled an industrial revolution of sorts. The entire setting has been thrown into a sort of hyper-capitalist frenzy by this process, even in parts of space that are not controlled by one of the human bodies of authority.

Non-human races also exist in the setting, some of whom have been around since the war of creation, and their texts would serve as an illuminating counterpoint to the histories penned by the human godheads and their respective scholars, as they were made from different perspectives and broadly with far less bias. They'd also reveal that the war was not fully won, and that a remnant of that great entropic force remains active, floating around the edge of the galaxy, lying dormant inside the corpse of a lost human progenitor deity named Hallow.

How do you writing geniuses convincingly? I'm talking about people, good or evil, that are smarter than even the person writing them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86729372
Basically take your time to really think through those character's thoughts. One of the common mistakes on "smart" characters is to just give them all the information out of nowhere which just makes them look like an author's favourite.
It can also help to adress some of the downsides of being a "genius". It's very common for gifted children to crash pretty hard later in life because you've never learned hard work, dedication or focus. Like, I got straight As in school while sitting in the back of class playing video games, but that shit didn't fly university or when doing that $10000 professional certification.

>>86718335
Do you mean literal crossovers or merging multiple sources into a new creation?

I have a distaste for the former. It really runs the danger of flanderizing the gods by trying to find equivalents, like how Hades often turns into a satan figure, and you can't really be faifthful to every mythology without, say, the Hindu panetheon steamrolling everything or everyone having to bow down to the Christian god. At best you create a new "species" where the individual characters take inspiration from various gods.
You also have the more practical problem of research active believers. The mythologies we have the most info about are also the ones with the most people to point out where you get things wrong and be really pissed of about that.

The latter is just normal worldbuilding, and I would even consider it best practice to always have at least three or more sources for whatever you create.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86732568
Wildly variable.
Medieval British, French, and German depictions are anything from about 7' to 30' or more. I'd say the most common height given in text is ten cubits, which is about 15'. Six cubits (like the biblical Goliath) is also popular. But in art, they generally seem smaller, often only about a head taller than normal people. Renaissance and later depictions tend to be bigger.
Lots of places have legends of giants creating landscape features, such as hurling rocks which turned into islands, or transforming into mountains on death. That implies really, really big giants. If you take some of the world-creation-giant stories literally, you have giants big enough to make planets out of.
On the other hand, lots of entities which get called 'giants' may not have been thought of as especially large. Norse giants are often not recognized as giants until they display magical powers, implying they were no bigger than other people (although those 'people' may not all have been humans, to add a bit more confusion). A common theme in Germanic romance is a giant who wears the armour of a legendary human hero, which implies human-like size (I think there are even texts where this theme appears alongside the same giant being explicitly much larger than a normal man).
Medieval Christians had a blurry line between humans and the 'monstrous races'. They knew that freakish children could come from normal parents, and generally saw that as the origin of most humanoid monsters, especially the giant / ogre / wildman archetype. If they were considered a separate 'race' it would be in the sense of a subspecies of human rather than entirely different. So they would be entirely willing to categorize someone suffering from gigantism (or maybe even just someone like 6' 6") as a 'giant', alongside fictional beings who were far larger.

The description of the dokkalfar (who are presumably the same as the svartalfar and the dwarves) as being pitch black can probably also be disregarded. The only description of a dwarf we get in prechristian poetry is of alviss in alvissmal who’s described as being pale and corpselike.
> Vanir and Aesir are VERY much separate.
We see them like that now, but like I said, the difference was read into the myths later by non-pagans, it wasn’t there by design. The term vanir is used almost exclusively as a synonym for aesir that can alliterate with words that start with v.

A fantasy setting can be as much of a cultural and aesthetic hodgepodge as you want it to be. You can have an elven paladin of Greek-like philosophy in Song dynasty armor, a barbarian zealot of Sekhmet blessed with the goddess's leonine ears and tail, a quick-draw hand crossbow cowboy in a poncho, a fox-eared and fox-tailed shrine maiden who practices divine wizardry, and a singing idol bard with an arcane microphone, all in the same party.

After all, your party's adventures might see them fighting Lovecraftian aberrations (American pulp fiction), mummies (Egyptian mythology), oni mages (Japanese mythology), genies (Islamic mythology), rakshasas (Hindu mythology), and dragon turtles (Chinese mythology).

Unless you want to stick to only one source of inspiration, anyway.

>How did the myths explain why they hadn't killed literally everyone with these powers?
There are examples of a single Draugr having indeed killed hundreds of people by themself, including a king, before finally being put down by a hero. But a fair amount of Draugar (but not all) seemed to keep themselves to a certain area, guarding their burial mound or terrorizing a specific farmstead or village. And whilst they aren't hurt by sunlight, they do appear to prefer being active during the night.
>Did they have any major weaknesses?
Whilst weapons can't kill nor truly stop them, iron can still injure them to some degree. But for actually defeating a Draugr, one way seems to be cutting of its head, burning its body, and then dumping the ashes in the sea to make sure its dead and gone. Basically destroying and separating the body into as many small pieces as possible and spreading them away. But the powers of Draugr also varied, and some could apparently be merely wrestled back to their grave with heroic strength and then maybe also just behead it and hide its head in a way that it can't find it.
But a lot of emphasis was also put on preemptively preventing a Dragur in the first place, by placing iron scissors on the deceased, tying their big toes together, needles in their feet, lifting and lowering the coffin in three different directions as it was carried to the burial mound, leaving no exit from the mound, etc.

threads.sub: Replacing MTG Mulligans with a Doubling Cube
threads.com:
What about making matches best 3/5 and removing mulligans? Instead, before the game, players can look at their opening hands and the person going second can either check, (match continues as normal), double down (game would count as two games in the match), fold (concede but continue with the set), or all-in (losing that game loses the match). The person on the play would have to agree to the same stakes dictated by the player on the draw or forfeit the round. There is probably a better way to codify exactly how this would work, but you get the idea.

Without ante or a similar gambling mechanic, there are certain hands that are unwinnable. Poker doesn't have this problem because you can just fold garbage like 10/2 off instead of having to get to the river and waste everyone's time. I think this might be interesting and also reduces shuffling and downtime. Instead of always choosing to be on the play, now there is also an incentive to be on the draw because you get to control the betting

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Many of us know the usual Blood War gimmick in a D&D context: demons and devils clashing on a massive and multiversal scale, often using whole mortal worlds as their battlefields. There might be yugoloths running around as some mix of mercenaries, profiteers, and manipulators. (In Eberron, this might instead be a clash between multiple simultaneously released fiendish overlords, some of which did not quite get along.)

But what if we add a wild card to the mix, something none of these fiends even remotely expect? Desperate times call for desperate measures. When the whispers of cosmic, aberrant powers promise salvation to a besieged world, who is to refuse them? Whether these eldritch forces are Mak Thuum Ngatha and Ragnorra, Caiphon and Allabar, Dyrrn and Belashyrra, Cthulhu and Shub-Niggurath, or some other mix of entities, they are willing to empower vast cults and lend a hand against the fiendish invaders. (In 13th Age, the Crusader wages war against demons, and the "dark gods" he is pledged to could very well be aberrant!) What happens if the fiends are driven away? Well, the world can work that out later, right?

As an alternative scenario, it could be that the forces originally plaguing the world are spooky aberrations to begin with. Then, fiendish powers start to offer their aid, establishing cults across the globe to drive back all the tentacles and extraneous eyeballs.

How would you run an adventure or a campaign which pits fiends (no pun intended) and aberrations against one another? What sort of interesting scenarios could PCs get involved in?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86728192
Well, that helps narrow it down.
Firstly I would recommend against a dnd reskin. Fundamentally, dnd is designed so that characters always get stronger and less vulnerable with time, probably not what you want.
What makes the best option will depend on how you want it to play. For example, delta green has a solid foundation and good systems for mental health and social relationship deterioration, and mechanics for becoming gradually inured to violence so thet you get that 1000 yard stare, good straightforward gun mechanics too, and a perfectly decent percentil skill system. It would lend itself to a game with brutal combat and deteriorating PCs.
Something gumshoe based might lend itself to survival since even your skills are resources. Its designed for mystery games, but "how do we get in to this building and find x?" And "how do we kill this creature?" Are mysteries it can be configured to presenting. The thing that would make it work for survival is that even its basic skill usages are spends, you can exhaust your character completely in a way you can't in other games.
Wouldn't recommend fate, for obvious reasons. Storyteller is functional.
Or as I mentioned, gurps, which can simulate anything as long as you like its approach to simulation.

>>86707472
Have you ever played the Legacy of Kain games? If not then I'd recommend that you do. If you have then have it be like Kain's Empire designed by H.R.Geiger. there's a lot of things that might have been human long ago or have had a human among their ancestors at some point. Most of the ones that aren't hostile are preoccupied with performing a specific task that might be understandable or might not and won't interact with you or anything even if attacked. There are predators that feed on them and will hunt you. The predators are more intelligent and will ambush you, use luring tactics and for preference will get you in your sleep. They can usually be talked to once you overcome the language barrier but they hate you and think of you as food.

The "cities" are giant limpet like creatures that the monotask creatures live in and maintain. They very slowly move across the world eating what's left of the old world. They aren't intelligent as such as they don't have to be, they just have highly sophisticated reactions to stimuli. The world is dead and it's corpse nearly picked clean, at some point in the near future the cities will turn on each other in cannibalistic war.

There might be surviving tribes of humans or near-humans in varying degrees of deviation or degeneration out in the wastelands but if so then they are on borrowed time.

The only "win" condition for the world as a whole is the extinction of the city-monsters and their broken denizens and even then it'll be thousands of years before anything really changes.
